review:
An interesting, albeit short, horror game about neurosis (as far as I can tell)

While I’m sceptical about the use of text in the beginning, things soon get interesting, coming together a twisted fairy-tale about the main character’s (Autumn) personal issues with her mother. 

There's a lot of symbolism going on. It's also a rare example of psychological horror that puts psychology first. Further, it's easy for us to appreciate as the player because the discordant sound effects creates an oppressive atmosphere to play match the characters' inner turmoil.

That’s arguably where the game stands out most. The gameplay parts are slightly more rudimentary (a lot of walking around and picking things up). 

So yeah, I'd recommend it if you like experimental and bleak.

review:
This game.

I'm not quite sure how to describe it.
While the game is short (1 hour, single playthrough), it somehow feels like a perfect length. The atmosphere is incredible and certainly does fit the 'psychological horror' tag in parts, but there's so much more to the game than just getting a cheap thrill. I found parts of it really disturbing, and the end made me sit back and think. So much emotion and empathy channeled into this small game.

I wholeheartedly recommend A Wolf in Autumn to anyone who wants a game, no, an experience that makes you consider the characters on a deeper level than what is shown on the surface.

review:
[h1]I love you, mom..[/h1]

Сразу стоит отметить, что хоррором это очень сложно назвать. Единственный «страшный момент», где пульс участился на пару ударов, это, внимание – спойлер, момент [spoiler]с волком в конце второй части[/spoiler]. И да, данный «хоррор» заставляет задуматься. После прохождения вы будете сидеть и не втыкать, что только что произошло. Внимание, вопросы, которые могут появиться на протяжении всей игры, спойлер: [spoiler]Кто такой волк? Откуда он взялся? Почему он обратился в тень? Почему мы находимся в клетке? Почему мать говорит нам, цитирую, «GET BACK IN YOUR FUCKING CAGE!!!»? Зачем ей все эти инструменты? Реально ли всё это? Куда пропадают комнаты?[/spoiler]. Но кажется я понял, ибо после прохождения игра нам предоставляется диалог между мамой и дочерью, в котором собственно и предоставляются некоторые детали. Опять же, моё мнение, что такое A Wolf in Autumn, спойлер:[spoiler]Autumn – не осень, здесь подразумевается имя, имя главной героини. Так вот «Волк внутри Autumn»  - просто кошмар, а сам волк олицетворяет страхи Autumn: постоянные крики матери, страшные сцены в подвале, и т.д. Но в конце, всё хорошо, они смотрят друг на друга с любовью, молча, и Autumn говорит «I love your mom…»[/spoiler]. Вот на такие мысли наводит игра, и это несомненно здорово. Но сюжет сюжетом, а что до деталей:

[h1]Плюсы:[/h1]
[list]
[*] [u]Интересный сюжет.[/u]
[*] [u]Элементы головоломки.[/u] По локации раскиданы предметы, каждый из которых подходит к чему-то определенному. 
[*] [u]Картинка.[/u] Играл на своем ноуте – ведре, лагало, пришлось играть в окне на Low. Но картинка приятная, осенние пейзажи, тени, и т.д.
 [/list]

[h1]Минусы:[/h1]
[list]
[*] [u]Нет русского языка.[/u]
[*] [u]Это не хоррор.[/u] Да, атмосфера в подвале немного нагнетала, но этого мало!
[/list]

[h1]Итог:[/h1]
Честно сказать, по началу хотел бросить игру, но сейчас очень рад, что не сделал этого. A Wolf in Autumn – игра на полчаса-час, которая подарит вам эмоций на куда большее время. Рекомендую!

author: {'steamid': '76561197996206648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1475543249}
review:
[i]A Wolf In Autumn[/i] is a very short story--scratch that, "tone poem"--disguised as a puzzle game. In comparison, the developer's earlier work, [i]Fingerbones[/i], was a short story that started with after the end of the world and went downhill from there: what happens if a guy who's read far too much Nietzsche for his own good survives the end of the world? Mr. Szymanski's sense of horror is primary psychological, and the psychological trigger he enjoys pulling most is transgression. [i]Fingerbones[/i] was a story that started mundane and, as the player went through the motions of a puzzle game, it slowly transgressed the usual player's conventional morals. By the end, you [i]know[/i] what's going to happen. You dread it, but, like craning one's neck at the grim-looking traffic accident, the sick part of your soul has to make sure.

[i]A Wolf In Autumn[/i] also gets its creepshow factor from transgression. However, unlike [i]Fingerbones[/i], it [i]starts[/i] walking past the line from the word go: you're a little girl. You're a nine-year-old girl, alone, locked in a shed by your mother. In Szymanski fashion, it all goes downhill from there. Lines are, of course, crossed and that is where [i]A Wolf In Autumn[/i] is most effective. It also does well with tension and suspense. There are one or two things that could be considered jump scares, but either they fall flat or I'm just not particularly susceptible to them and they're the game's weakest part.

Don't buy [i]A Wolf In Autumn[/i] for gameplay or expansive content, since it is only about an hour long. Those will inevitably disappoint you if you put much value in them. Buy it and play it if you want... a poem. A feeling. A theme. If [i]Fingerbones[/i] was about the potential barbarism in people well past the pale of everyday existence, [i]A Wolf In Autumn[/i] looks to things closer to home. By the end of the game, you'll realize you probably know at least one person that this tone poem comes dangerously close to describing. Depending on where you live, that person might live down the street and there may be a handful of them to boot.

If you're particularly unlucky, you might find it speaks to your own condition.

review:
Another strange game from a guy who specializes in strange games.

I actually liked this one more than Fingerbones and The Moon Sliver. This one felt more personal and intimate, plus it had much creepier effects, like dogs whimpering.

Anyways, you play as a young girl in a shack in the middle of a forest. After breaking you, you must figure out smal puzzles in the environment while a woman claiming to be your mother becomes increasingly hostile towards you as you make progress.

This was a really interesting one, with lots left open to interpretation. But like I said, the atmosphere is good and it's a good game to think about. I personally had a much more gruesome take on the game than others have, but I'm not sure how intentional that was. Anyways, this is worth a look when it'son sale for dirt cheap. Another solid game. Next up is the Music Machine.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059425204', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1466323517}
review:
A wolf in Autumn is a very interesting game. You play as Autumn as you try to continue through the story line. I can get a general idea of what the storyline is, the main aspects are obvious but the whole story is quite a mystery to me. I think that it is trying to be a bit like Undertale in how the truth is hidden and the story was quite unknown until the end but how we find out what happened was through text on a screen instead of learning through playing.

I feel like a puzzle tag needs to be added to the game description as there was a big element of puzzles and mysteries. There wasn't as much horror as I was expecting, there wasn't really a scary be but more that 90% of the game felt eerie.

I think that one of the main problems was that there was only like a half hour of the game but give or take for time getting stuck makes it about an hour long. I feel that the short time of the game made it hard to develop the story. I did like the fact that there is no save and that you are supposed to play the game in a 1 hour sitting (roughly) as this is something interesting that I haven't really seen before.

Overall - Did like the ideas and the concepts. Also liked the realism and thought that it was good at making the player feel eerie. Didn't lime the timing however, as a longer story could have allowed for it to develop more. To conclude, I would recomend this game and I think it is good quality for the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993502256', 'num_games_owned': 2488, 'num_reviews': 232, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1466266086}
review:
Hübsch, wenn auch nicht von Dauer.

A Wolf in Autumn ist ein Spiel, wo der erste Blick sagt: Hey! Das sieht gut aus! Und tatsächlich. Die Beleuchtung ist sehr schön gestaltet, wie auch die Umgebung. Auch die Sounds sind gut gelungen, sowie das Voice-Acting. Ich zumindest habe die Mutter sehr gut verstanden und das ohne Untertitel.

Spielerisch muss man jedoch ein paar Abstriche machen. Das Spiel ist kurz und hat kein Speichersystem, worauf netterweise aber hingewiesen wird. Man sollte etwa eine Stunde Zeit haben, bevor man beginnt. Wir rätseln uns dann durch einen Traum, der vorerst ja wie ein schöner Traum aussieht, jedoch immer dunklere Gestalten annimmt.

Im Großen und Ganzen kann man also sagen: Wer eine Geschichte erzählt haben will, wo man hier und da etwas nachdenken muss, der kann sich das Spiel anschauen. Wer hier knackige Rätsel erwartet und so richtige Horrorstimmung, sollte lieber etwas anderes suchen, wobei ich nicht sagen möchte, dass das Spiel nicht gruselig ist. Es baut eine beklemmende Atmosphäre auf und so einige Male zögert man doch, bevor man sich umdreht.

Kaufempfehlung ja, aber nur weil der Preis ohnehin schon sehr niedrig ist.

author: {'steamid': '76561198280371208', 'num_games_owned': 838, 'num_reviews': 272, 'playtime_forever': 62, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1465981918}
review:
So it has been interesting playing through all the games this developer has made (excluding the collab game) and seeing how affective the story telling has become. I have always wondered how their games would be if voice acting was added and it is not disappointing. It would not be the same if it was just text and it was a good choice for at least using it for the mother. As the style has changed, it is used to bring a more realistic look, using effects that works well for this style to make the world have more effect. If it was like previous games, it would not have had the same effect on the player. 
I only found two things that was wrong with it, but otherwise small. I couldn't pick up the lighter in the basement after droppping it, so I had to restart the game. I'm sure this is like a low chance of this happening though. The second thing is when you are loading to the basement, the game can crash/not respond. It wasn't a big deal as it was the beginning, but it's not really a big deal anyway considering the game is short enough to not be concerned with losing your progress.
Overall, this game is not disappointing. I find it hilarious when I get spooked by something I shouldn't have in the game (it was really embarrassing when I got scared by the lights seemingly lining up to look like eyes in the bush. I have an odd feeling those were placed like that on purpose. Coinsidence? I think not). I'm really glad the puzzle in the beginning could be solved two ways because I did not notice one of the ways [spoiler] aka the key hanging down that could be cut with the scissors the first time I played the beginning part (I'm glad I found out as that note might not have made sense haha) [/spoiler] .
If the developer decides to continue making games, I certainly will be looking forward to seeing the improvements and engaging in another world made by them. I'm sure I got pretty annoying showing up suddenly reviewing all the games suddenly. Ending thoughts: Don't esculate this quickly mother, you seriously messed with my head.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072006918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1465768366}
review:
This short game starts and ends with lines after lines of purple prose -- paragraph-long sentences without a single punctuation mark. Between them lies what can be best described as purple prose in form of game mechanic. It tries to make a point, to tell a story of a troubled girl, her inner struggles and relationship with her mother. The game's creator knows his environmental storytelling tools well (probably too well) and applies them as much as possible, trying to create a story through objects and rooms, rather than text. Then, probably realizing it doen't work, he goes back to telling the story through monologues. Either way, both the story and its characters are vague and pointless, ultimately going nowhere. 
As a diploma project in a game design school thit would probably earn the author an A. As an actual game to buy with your money and put an hour into playing, it doesn't deserve any attention.

review:
Well this is my first review, so I\'ll make it interesting with a personal interpretation. Read this only after you've played the game and you have your own opinion of it :) Otherwise, you know - SPOILERS :)

So this game, I feel is obviously about the drama between a mother and her daughter. The mother has lead a heavy, very heavy life, full of mistakes, full of wrongs. She has only her pride left... barely.The daughter sences this and much more. She feels her mother's pain and wants to help her. But she's refused. The game takes place in a nightmare, hence all the tripping colours and weird machinations. At first I asked myself if this is a metaphore for a womb and escaping from it. Close to the end you cut some bloody ropes, which remind me of umbelical cords. 

I believe the mother can\'t let her child go and wants to protect her from the evil in the world... I honestly feel for her. I have a friend for whom I have the same feelings. That's why Autumn is in a cage, going in circles, always thinkering with stuff. Which makes her mother furious: she can\'t control things she doesn\'t understand! That\'s why she stops her constantly.

At one point you are attacked by a spectre of a black wolf. I honestly shivered in my entire body, such a good moment. I believe the wolves represent the evils that might afflict women: abuse, a wasted life, dead hopes and so on. The game is both very sad and very scary, when you really think about it. If you know someone, a man or woman, who might be abused - help them, be there for them. And love your children... I think this game is about those things...

Thank you for reading, and to the creator(s) keep making games like this :)

review:
A very strange psychological horror puzzle game. Very strange indeed.

The game is short, I completed it in ~40 minutes.

The puzzles well.. I hate to call them puzzles but technically they are puzzles, so yea, the puzzles aren't to hard. Once you've played it for about 3 minutes you get the hang of it and things shouldn't be to difficult, but they are made in a clever way. But if you're stuck just use a walkthrough, nothing wrong with that.

I mean.. I don't really know how to properly review this game.

You play as a little girl with one hand as I understand it, you're in a locked in a shed which you complete a [i]puzzle[/i] to get out of, you then recieve a message from your mother, once you progress in the game you get more increasingly aggresive messages from your mother.

The gameplay for what kind of game it is, is great, the story is... fine(when I say story I mean the dialouge and the text you're introduced with/the game ends with).
If you're familiar with this developers previous games then expect the same atmosphere, and strange game in a different setting.
This developer really knows how to do psychological horror the right way, great to play in the dark.
The game is grim, the atmosphere is dark.

It's hard to not spoil the story when talking about it so I wont. Experience it for yourself.

I don't want to go into it more. Try it for yourself when you're in the right mindset, it's short and cheap, nothing to lose.

But, as always with these games, you have to play it when you're in the right mood/mindset to properly enjoy it, to get what you want out of it.
I think everyone who already enjoy games like these, strange games, walking simulators etc... know what I am talking about.
I personally don't think you can just go into a game like [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/232430/]Gone Home[/url] at anytime, you have to be in the correct mood to really enjoy it.
If you know you're not in the right mood then wait and play it when you are in the correct mood. 

By the way the starting area of the game has extremely bright colours, they actually made my eyes weird.. I don't know how to explain, so if you have any health related issues with that then don't play this.



*One thing I always recommend developers of games like this is add some achievements. It does sell your game to completionists who want 100% achievements in games. It doesn't take much effort to add some, just do it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040892359', 'num_games_owned': 3008, 'num_reviews': 369, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1458031136}
review:
Hmmm... Just finished this game, so thought I'd write a short review.

I enjoyed the story. It wasn't at all what I thought it'd be, which is by no means a bad thing. This is more of an example of 'the game existing simply to be a vessel for the story,' rather than a game with a story tacked on as an afterthought. (if that makes any sense?)

I generally enjoy games with a good and/or mature story, as they seem to be hard to come by. A Wolf in Autumn certainly delivered. While I was hoping to see relationships or inspirations from the things the dev mentioned (Sound and the Fury, Silent Hill 2, Mulholland Drive) as I love each one, I could find nothing. Not going to knock any points though. (Although on a personal note, I'd be curious to know what about/what parts of the game the dev feels were inspired by these things.)

I did pick up the developer's other two games as well, and I'm looking forward to seeing if they are just as engaging.

A few... well, not really cons, per say...

I've got a i7 5930 and a ASUS Strix GTX 980Ti. I can run GTA V in three screen surround mode maxed out and my temps don't get as high as they do in this game playing in 1920*1080 borderless windowed. Generally my CPU temp is 28-33C at idle depending on ambient room temp, and GPU is 30-34C. This game had the CPU up to 45C and the GPU up to 76C. I opened my GPU manager and set a custom fan profile, which I've never done before, simply because of the extreme temp increase this game caused. It just seems like this game may not be very well optimized. 

Last thing is that, if you are epileptic or have photosensitive seizures, The contrast in the opening area, as well as the choice of lighting can make it hard on your eyes and head. Soon after you reach the basement, there will also be a badly flickering overhead light. A few minutes after the basement light came on, my head hurt so bad and I felt so drained I had to take an extended break. (Hence the long play time for what is a very short game.) So just be aware.

All in all, good game, great story and well worth the asking price. Enjoy.

review:
Encore une belle et tragique promenade en compagnie de David Szymanski, le temps d'un "A Wolf in Automn" dans la droite ligne de ses précédents travaux.
Paisible, beau, littéraire.
Plus un livre d'images, elliptique et glaçant, qu'un jeu à part entière.
Quelques énigmes dont la résolution tombe sous le sens.
Quelques errances sur fond d'introversion.
Les couleurs chatoyantes d'un ciel d'automne.
Des thématiques dures et sans concessions.
Quelques frissons, quelques symboles.
Un parti-pris, une fois de plus, qui rebutera ou séduira selon ce qu'on cherche ou ne cherche pas dans un titre de ce genre, mais avec la générosité créative d'un seul homme comme gage d'authenticité.

Si ce nouveau récit est toujours construit avec intelligence, l'anglais y est toutefois plus ardu que dans The Moon Sliver. Le fond, plus douloureux. Moins éthéré. Plus proche de Fingerbones (dont il se fait presque le remake).

Aussi n'aurai-je pas été autant bouleversé que précédemment (et ai-je dû consulter le net pour vérifier que j'avais bien compris de quoi il retournait).
Aussi n'aurai-je pas été autant happé.
Mais conquis ?

Incontestablement.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988012862', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 326, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1454740146}
review:
Short psychological horror adventure.

Mechanically, you need to open a few locks, throw some switches, light some candles, that sort of thing. You can hold one item at a time to carry and use and drop, but there are duplicates of the important ones. The mechanics make this an adventure, but that's not what it is about.

This game appeals more to the emotions than to logic. Who are we, where are we, and why is everything so strange and fearsome? Even more than in the free [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/391270/]Fingerbones[/url], Szymanski manages to aim from the surreal straight into a reality that is uncomfortably close to home. There are no cheap tricks, the chills does not stem from the unknown, but from reminding us of the known that is so terrifying.

The 3D modeling is crude but effective, the sound effects and voice carry the game.

The game is only about an hour long. The author recommends that it be played in one sitting (you can't save), and with headphones, and while you can do the headphones or not (a good sound system is probably better), having an hour in a dimly lit room with no distractions seems a good way to play this.

It's good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036649624', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1631848913}
review:
I recommend this game, but it's a tepid thumbs up.  I'm a solid fan of this developer in general, but I don't think this is his best.  

First, I've played through it twice now and the story is... less clear than I would like.  That's both good and bad.  The story is clear enough that I know it's not supposed to be clear.  I'm fairly sure I understand the high-level backstory behind the two characters.  I'm also reasonably sure I understand the "perspective" that causes some of the rapid swings in the environment and other oddities.  But there's the lingering sense that I'm missing something.  A feeling as if I've managed to figure out the backstory while somehow overlooking the plot.  It's odd.  What I think I understand isn't a bad story -- it has some very intriguing themes going.  It's just that they don't seem to be going forward.  At all.  Like unearthing the backstory IS the story, but nothing moves forward once you grasp the setup.

Second, though the game does explain why you don't have an inventory...  I'm still more inclined to just call the interface "unfinished."

Third, it can be REALLY hard to see where you're going the first time you play.  This has pros and cons.  Pros: atmospheric, very pretty, appropriately creepy.  Cons: can occasionally get lost in a seemingly infinite black void because you can't tell the difference between lack of light and walls.

All in all, rough around some edges, but an interesting experience I wish we saw a lot more of!

review:
♦ Spielinhalt:
Du spielst ein etwa 9 Jähriges Mädchen, allein und gefangen in einer Hütte, aus der du entkommen möchtest. Einmal befreit kommst du in einer Art Minigarten an und es passieren seltsame Dinge, unter anderem das deine Mutter aus einem steinartigen Etwas mit einem Knopf, wie durch ein Telefon mit dir kommunizieren kann. 


[+]
● atmosphärisch - aber etwas zu grell, meiner Meinung nach
● Besonders bei dem Rätsel, wie ich aus der Hütte kommen sollte hatte ich keinen blassen Schimmer, aber ansonsten doch sehr simple Rätsel
● es gibt nur eine Synchronsprecherin - was ich bisher in keinem Spiel gesehen habe, es aber auch nicht unbedingt sympathischer macht
● baut auf psychologischem Horror auf - gibt zwar ein Jumpscare, aber das ist nicht besonders gruselig. Mehr die allgemeine Atmosphäre des Spiels

[-]
●  es ist grafisch nicht besonders anspruchsvoll
● kein Spiel das länger als eine halbe Stunde - maximal eine Stunde Zeit in Anspruch nimmt
● Du kannst nur ein Item zur selben Zeit halten (einer 9-Jährigen fehlt scheinbar die Kraft dazu zwei Gegenstände zu halten)

♦ Fazit:
Es ist kein schlechtes Spiel. Das auf keinen Fall, aber für meinen Geschmack leider viel zu kurz um einen guten Eindruck davon zu bekommen.  Aber wer keine Muße für ein längeres Spiel hat und nur Mal kurz was gegen Langeweile sucht wird mit A Wolf in Autumn sicher nicht enttäuscht. Außerdem sollte ihr vielleicht eine Vorliebe für Psycho Horror haben, da sich dieser durch die Atmosphäre aufbaut und nicht durch Jumpscares ausmacht.

review:
[i]David Szymanski n'a pas chômé en 2015 en développant pas moins de quatre jeux, courts certes, mais quatre jeux tout de même ! Pour ceux qui ne connaissent pas le travail de Szymanski, il faut savoir qu'il aime l'horreur psychologique, simple, sans jumpscares mais avec une ambiance travaillée, intense, qui se base sur un récit complexe et laisse le champ libre aux interprétations.[/i]

Une petite fille se réveille enfermée dans une grange. Une clé retenue par un fil pend à mi-hauteur et lui permet de s'évader rapidement. La voilà dans un enclos au milieu d'une forêt automnale, idyllique avec les reflets rougeoyants que laisse le soleil en traversant les feuilles des grands arbres, un décor presque surréaliste. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=604743726 Au centre de cet enclos, une étrange machine est reliée à une porte close menant sous la terre. Une sonnerie retentit, la voix de sa mère se fait entendre à travers un drôle de caisson en tôle. "Reste tranquille ma chérie, retourne dans la grange, ne touche à rien et surtout pas à la porte du sous-sol". Cette ambiance rassurante va lentement se muer en atmosphère pesante. Un sombre secret se cache dans cette forêt et les hurlements des loups se rapprochent dangereusement... 

Comme souvent avec Szymanski les jeux sont courts et pensés pour être joués en une seule fois afin de ne pas altérer l'ambiance particulière d'un conte aussi noir. Ainsi, il faudra vous assurer d'avoir au moins 1h à consacrer à ce jeu puisqu'il ne possède pas de système de sauvegarde. Rassurez-vous, si vous devez quitter vous n'aurez pas de mal à recommencer rapidement étant donné qu'une fois que l'on sait quoi faire le jeu peut se terminer en 15 minutes.

La première chose qui saute aux yeux, c'est la beauté et la poésie visuelle de A Wolf in Autumn. Bien que techniquement il reste des choses à améliorer il ne faut pas oublier que c'est le travail d'un seul homme et qu'il a réussi a montrer le grand potentiel du moteur Unity 5, ce n'est pas le cas de tous les jeux indépendants qui s'en servent, loin de là. Cette forêt colorée, saturée en couleurs avec ses beaux reflets est un régal à regarder. Le contraste est d'autant plus saisissant avec le second environnement du jeu : une cave sombre et lugubre. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=604743750 L'effet est radical. On passe du rêve au cauchemar.

Seconde particularité du jeu après l'absence du système de sauvegarde, l'absence d'inventaire. Et pourtant on en aurait eu besoin car on va devoir chercher des objets tels des tournevis, clés, torches et fusibles pour résoudre les puzzles. Cela s'explique par le fait que nous incarnons une petite fille à qui il manque un bras. Elle doit donc se débrouiller avec une seule main et pour plus d'immersion, le choix de ne pas intégrer d'inventaire a été fait. Aussi, un tel choix nous oblige à prêter attention à l'endroit où l'on pose les objets et à s'en souvenir, le joueur est d'emblée plus impliqué dans le déroulement des actions. Pas d'inquiétude cependant, les puzzles peuvent souvent se résoudre de diverses manières et plusieurs objets d'un même type sont généralement disponibles. Les énigmes ne sont d'ailleurs pas bien compliquées, l'intérêt du jeu réside davantage dans le récit lugubre qui nous est fait.

A Wolf in Autumn est le premier jeu pour lequel le développeur a fait appel à une actrice, ici pour doubler les dires de la mère. Cela apporte énormément car la voix est excellente et dégage beaucoup de caractère avec ses intonations, ses accents mielleux, et ses tons machiavéliques. Le seul regret reste que ces phases ne soient pas sous-titrées. Les lignes de dialogue sont simples à comprendre mais on peut facilement manquer des mots par-ci par-là selon les actions que l'on effectue en simultané. Lorsqu'on a affaire à des pensées de la fillette, les sous-titres sont aussi un peu trop rapides à mon goût, surtout que ce n'est pas le genre de jeu où il faut prendre les informations par dessus la jambe. Tout est important pour comprendre ce qui se passe réellement dans cette forêt. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=604743820 La technique utilisée dans les textes d’introduction et de conclusion du jeu est tout à fait originale, cela s'appelle du "courant de conscience", une sorte de monologue intérieur qui ne se plie pas aux codes de l'écriture et oublie ainsi des règles telles que la ponctuation. Ce n'est pas toujours très facile à suivre et un bon niveau d'anglais est tout de même requis. 

La bande-son réalisée par Szymanski est bonne elle-aussi, décidément c'est l'homme à tout faire. Si vous avez joué à The Music Machine vous reconnaitrez certaines sonorités déjà utilisées par le développeur, une vraie personnalité s'en dégage ainsi qu'une atmosphère pesante qui sied parfaitement au jeu. Malgré tout j'ai trouvé les compositions supérieures et plus variées dans The Music Machine mais ce jeu-là durait aussi un peu plus longtemps. Pour un aperçu de l'OST de A Wolf in Autumn c'est [url=https://davidszymanski.bandcamp.com/album/a-wolf-in-autumn-ost]par ici.[/url]

En tout et pour tout, il faut savoir à quoi s'attendre quand on s'attaque à un jeu signé David Szymanski. Original, court, surprenant, A Wolf in Autumn prend le pari de nous livrer, en 1h seulement, les clés de compréhension d'une réalité sombre au travers d'une écriture subtile et réfléchie. Les indices sont nombreux, il ne tient qu'à vous de savoir les interpréter.

review:
[h1]This is the story of a short girl with one arm who just wants out of her shed.[/h1]

[spoiler]Her mother is possessed by drugs and no one deserves that horror, however I think she may deserve the one arm.[/spoiler] Let's just say it's complicated.

A Wolf in Autumn is an eerily intriguing adventure, with some nice puzzles that actually require logic as opposed to traditional adventure shenanigans. You'll explore a bit, use a few tools, and do a few things, all while piecing together the story. Few horror games are about such a realistic subject; a literal scourge on humanity.

[spoiler][i]Drugs are bad, mmm'kay?[/i][/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198014766672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 398, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1452269912}
review:
[h1]This game was reviewed using a code sent by the developer.[/h1]

A Wolf in Autumn is a short puzzle adventure game that was released in October 2015, being developed by David Szymanski. As you get told when launching the game, it is intended that you finish it in one sitting, which takes about an hour. 

You play the game as a young girl, and you find yourself in a forest at the start of the game, locked in a shed by your mother. To begin with your mother and surroundings seem very peaceful, but this soon takes a dark turn. Gameplay is from a first person perspective, and the main tasks involve solving puzzles that use real world logic. The puzzles do require some thought though; you shouldn’t be put off by the starting area as that is the one I found the most difficult. I’m not ashamed to say I spent at least ten minutes trying to get out of the shed only for the answer to be extremely obvious. You are able to pick up objects, but sadly you can only have on item in your possession at a time, meaning a lot of running back and forth to get items is required. 

The game is run using the Unity 5 engine, and whilst the graphics aren’t the best, they do portray the darkness and surreal atmosphere very well. The game does have some nice lighting effects as well. It can be run on pretty much any resolution up to and including 4k.  The voice acting of your mother is very well done too; I genuinely got scared towards the end of the game just from the sound of her voice. 

Whilst there isn’t a very deep plot to this game, there are still some underlying potentially disturbing themes on show, and is not something which people who are easily upset by such things as child abuse should take lightly.  Maybe the developer is trying to show us something through the story, I don’t know, but I found it very interesting to see how the plot unfolded. 

As you can see from the amount of time to play the game, I didn’t find it all that difficult. If you apply logic to the puzzles, you can easily work them out, and often just pausing for a moment and thinking how you would get out of this situation yourself is usually the write answer.  I completed the game in about half an hour.  Some might think that is short for any game, and I can see why, but I was enthralled with the game from the get-go so I am not going to complain too much about the shortness.  I have seen that you can complete puzzles in more than one way as well; this may add a little replicability but I am more than happy with just the one play through to satisfy my experience with this title. 

I didn’t have any technical problems whilst playing; it is running on a very well matured engine so it should be expected. 

I enjoyed my time playing A Wolf in Autumn, not all horror experiences have to include an abundance of jump scares to be classed as scary; the atmosphere and undertones of this game are scary enough for me. The price of £1, 59 is fair, regardless of the length of the game. The developer has put plenty of hours into making a really good game, and that is definitely worth the £1, 59 in my eyes.

review:
Для начапа я напомню, что эта игра - в первую очередь адвенчура, а не хоррор и не валькин симулятор с философским смыслом, как многих может ввести в заблуждение соответствие названия и картинок.

С другой стороны, было довольно забавно представить на месте героя именно волка, собственно поначалу ты и думаешь из-за маленького роста, что ты и есть запертый в сарае в лесу дикий зверь.

С первых же кадров отсылки к потокам сознания недвусмысленно говорят о принадлежности игры, но тут скорее отсылка к "Когда я умирала" чем к "Шуму и ярости". Хотя в "The Sound and The Fury" слово "Машина" встречается 63
раза, но в значении именно "автомобиль", в "As I Lay Dying" всего 4, но по делу
cf.Потому  что создал нас Господь для дела, а не для того, чтобы чересчур долго думали;  мозги, они как машина, не любят, чтобы в них зря копались.
Ключевой смысл трактовки в формулировке внешнего мира как отлаженной машины, в противовес сомневающемуся и совершающему некие действия внутреннему миру человека
Хотя многие считают, что лучшие достойнейшие книги лучше читать в бумаге, я более склонен к утверждению, что части выполненые потоком сознания лучше воспринимаются на слух, когда их зачитывает - если герой женщина - женское лицо, без определенного эмоционального выделения. Так и здесь, больше геймеров обратили бы внимание на силу текста, если бы он давался не на черном фоне, а зачитывался мамочкой также, как и в процессе геймплея.
более опытные писатели в постмодернизме не вкладывали в монолог женщины такие сильные чувства, тем более не делали на них акцент
Попытки мужчины отобразить переживания женщины никогда не были удачными учитывая и эгоистичный намек "Может ли женщина думать?" Поток сознания от женского лица всегда очень тонкий и нелегкий приём. Сражаются гордость женщины с попыткой мужчины художника стать на время её разсудком. Попытка отобразить эгоизм и я-ориентированные чувства женщины через эгоизм и я-ориентацию мужчины. Эти попытки не всегда бывают удачны. Только когда они представляют собой модернистский памфлет, вызов, они начинают казаться влитой частью произведения.
Например, Сорокин в "Теллурии" может позволить себе то, на что не был способен в "Норме" - выразить поток рассказа девушки или может скорее женщины, при этом не акцентируя внимание на бьющие ключом чувства в результате вся вставка является прекрасным стилистическим приёмом, не мешающая ничему.
Хочется заметить, что поверить в то, что произошедшее было сном, может лишь недалекий в мистификациях авторов произведений человек. при этом мы играем явно не за девочку ведь Чуткий игрок замечает, что персонаж не может являться ни волком (как может он подумать вначале), ни собственно девочкой. Хотя воспринимаемая им информация не подвергается материальному мыслительному анализу, как раз это более наклоняет нас к тому, что персонаж мужчина лет 33. Происходящее не может быть кошмаром или детским сном, да и недалекие игроки думают что кошмар заключается в волках, дак нет, кошмар - это травма детства, нанесенная противоречием между замещением роли матери собой в результате недостаточности её реализации. Мать - эгоистична, делает вид что дает гарантии безопасности, но подсознательно-то мы понимает, что это враньё. Именно когда символы первобытной веры поставлены под сомнение, мы начинаем действовать ручками, сопротивляясь мессаджам от мамы.
Поэтому от игрока - требуется, необходимо - поставить под сомнение и эту мистификацию и понять, что подобная травма больше напоминает травму отца, когда именно отец, а не мать представляет из себя одновременно и существо, которое дает безопасность, и при этом существо которое твой организм отвергает.
Поэтому концовка реальная выглядит довольно наивным, если ты это понял.
Вторая часть (Basement)  игры довольно спорная. Смысла и посыла в ней меньше, чем в других, в более лучшем варианте она должна была бы являться посредником между началом и концом. Предполагаю, что создатели сделали упор здесь на хоррор-квест  ради форматности игры. Гораздо лучше было бы избавиться от предрассудков направленности для аудитории (ведь всё равно они не смогли бы узнать смысл второй части уже не купив её)) а сделать вторую часть связующим проводником.
(не влазит, дальше в комменты)

author: {'steamid': '76561198098942259', 'num_games_owned': 9622, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1483308255}
review:
A weird game but interesting i have to say.

*This game has alot of colours that are very bright, so if you suffer from anything like photophobia or anything similar please be aware.
It can also be hard to see parts of the outdoor scenery/objects sometimes because of this, so also bare that in mind.

Il start off with the graphics, whilst being a very bright game (part of it) the graphics are nothing amazing but good enough to play and enjoy, low budget you might say.

The story itself is a little freaky and makes you wonder at times WTF is going on, but if you read and follow it as you go you will eventually understand, it doesnt take long really (about 1hr or less) and isnt a bad short story overall, and although its a type of horror its not very scary at all.

The gameplay, movement, controls etc there pretty normal, theres no menu as such you just start off with a list and explanation of controls and enter the game or exit.
The basic idea of the game is to explore and find objects that will help you progress further in the game/story, kinda like puzzle solving but not really hard at all, and the area your in is pretty small so its not like your looking for a needle in a haystack, straightforward and simple to get used to tho and enough to keep you on track with the story.

Bad points? There isnt any exactly, IMO there could have been more in depth puzzles, bigger areas and more content to explore but for the price you pay i cant complain, and im sure theres people out there who dont enjoy puzzles being too in depth or tedious anyway.

Overall a great little game (and little it is) one your only gonna play through once, easy to understand, easy to play, with a freaky storyline that keeps you on your toes until the end and a few not so cryptik puzzles along the way, just wear sunglasses is all i can say :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198062707423', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1667929557}
review:
The game is not too bad, it is to able give you a fairly unsettling experience without being obvious about it , as in not constantly using jump scares as most other games would use. The overall art design of the game is stunning and really adds to the haunting atmosphere David Szymanski was trying to create , however what really makes the atmosphere in my opinion is the music and subtle sound effects that make you doubt yourself and have a quick look around your area to make sure you are still alone. Along with great atmosphere the story itself is quite interesting as you start off not knowing anything about your character and it is only with more exploration and progress you delve deeper into the dark fathoms of your characters life.

However there are a few things that could be improved on , such as constantly having to drop one item to pick up another, which is explained why, but drags the game out a little longer when it really doesn't have to as there is a point where you end up in a dark room and you can't keep your flashlight on you whilst using other items . Although it does state it is a short horror game I had it completed in like 30 minutes or so which you could argue is worth the 79p I paid for it as it is a really good experience and I guess I am left with wanting a bit more , but the more I am wanting is perhaps more backstory to the character and a bit more explanation. But then again the game does give you enough and I guess you are left to finish it off in your head.

Overall i would give the a game a 7/10 based on how cheap I got it and how much I enjoyed playing it.

Worth a playthrough at least.

review:
I'd been meaning to replay this game a second time before submitting a review, mainly because of some plot developments that really demand a second viewing in order to contextualize properly the things that are happening in the game. 

I did play the devs' previous games multiple times, but I have to admit, part of the reason why I'd taken so long here was because AWIA SCARES me. People may differ on what they conceive as horror, but for me, this is a horror game. Yes, it continues the sort of exploratory and puzzle style with focus on narration and story from the dev's previous games, but it is terrifying to me.

It begins with some text that appears straightforward, but then gets increasingly intense as the text screens progress, accompanied by some very aptly ominous music. And that's just the prologue before the game begins. You awaken to find yourself in a bright, oversaturated, and mesmerizing arboreal environment. And things seem pleasant again. Yeah, you're locked in a shed, but you easily get out, and you're able to communicate with your mom. But as you begin to explore your surroundings, things get more unnerving, and you find yourself feeling more vulnerable.

That's much as I can really describe of the setting without spoiling anything. The story in AWIA is a bit vague and unclear at first (and even a little after a second viewing), but it's not a disservice to the game. It's a very surreal experience, and the game does an excellent job of slowly giving more information to the player about who you are and what is going on. It's actually done very well, and adds to why the game is so scary to me. I can't really say much, but just the little bits of flavor text when you pick up certain items, or enter certain areas help to convey, although not so subtly, very organically, bits and pieces of your character (like why you can only carry one item at a time). 

Speaking of flavor text, the dev mentioned to me in a previous comment how one of the things he added in The Music Machine, was a larger variety of objects in the world to interact with because he felt that it added immersion. I definitely agree, and it was one of the things I liked in TMM versus The Moon Sliver. It gets even better in this game. When you attempt to use certain objects to deal with certain puzzles, there's actually unique text describing why your item doesn't work, instead of a generic “this item does not work here”. It's great, and I could be wrong, but I think there are also different ways to solve some of the different puzzles. All this just adds to the immersion, that you really are a little girl just fumbling around trying to figure stuff out.

And as you try to figure stuff out, the game may seem a bit slow at the beginning (at least it was for me, because I could not figure out many of the puzzles without quite a bit of roaming about because the...trigger points aren't as obvious), but it's quite rewarding, and like many good horror films...it gets increasingly disturbing as you progress, until you get to the final sequence and it's just snowballing in your face.

Overally, I greatly recommend this if you're into the previous games by the dev. And even if you weren't, I feel like you might have a different opinion about this. The game is much more intense. The puzzles are much more interesting. And the voice acting is incredible (as I said, this game legitimately scares me. It's emotionally taxing for all sorts of reasons). The story and characters seem rich. I say seem, because again, it's a bit unclear. But as I said, it's not a bad thing, and I look forward to additional plays, and looking through internet discussions to piece together exactly what is going on between the girl and her mother.

The graphics are gorgeous, and very fitting as you'll find. The music is excellent as with the dev's previous works. And at the end of the day. It's cheap, it's a quick play (under an hour). If you're looking for a quick, immersive, horror experience but with more emotional and narrative substance, I'm not sure you can really do better than this.

review:
It's hard to put words down without inadvertantly giving away spoilers. I'll try my best, however.

While this is a short game, it is certainly not a bad game. In fact, I enjoyed it quite a bit. The colours almost seem to bleed out in this game, particularly in the outdoors area. In my eyes, that is intentional and you will understand why as you get further into the game.

Little creepy touches add a nice feeling to the game. Reading the descriptions that Autumn says when clicking on items can shed a lot of light on what is really going on.

One thing did annoy me a little, and that was the fact that I had to drop the flashlight to pick up a different item. Depending on how far the location is that you need to use the other item, you can find yourself stuck in the dark for a bit. That certainly was not enough to dampen my enjoyment of the game.

This is a game that will make you think at the end of it, and may induce you to play it again just to see how differently you see things at the beginning, and how they tie into the end.

I highly recommend this game as it is a lot of fun and does make you think about it after you have reached the end.

review:
Well, this was another stellar game by one of my favorite developers, David Syzmanski. As with his previous works, he takes a psychological horror concept and really drives it home using minimalistic and yet lush and evocative scenery with a short tale attached. To tell you any more than what is in the store page would be a disservice to a person wishing to play this, so I wont go into my personal thoughts on the story, but I will say that it is quite compelling.

This time around, the Unity 5 engine, but without using stock assets. This marks an evolution in Mr Syzmanski's development ideas and skills. Actually, if you were to play each of his games in order of release, you would easily be able to track a clear progression is ability and skill, with this game as the current culmination of his previous efforts.

As with previous games, this game makes heavy use of the interplay between light, darkness, and shadow to emphasize the desired atmosphere. Additionally, the original soundtrack and sounds further enhance the experience. All was done in outstanding fashion.

Another appealing aspect of this game was the 45 minute to 1 hour length. In my opinion, it was the perfect length to accomplish the goals it sets out to accomplish.

The controls are simple WASD with R/L mouse to pick up, use, and drop items, and shift to run, since walking around exploration games slowly is always something of a chore (in my opinion. I appreciate it when devs include running despite it not being strictly necessary).

The puzzles in this game were not too difficult to solve, but were clever, making good use of the items available in the game without getting in the way of the experience.

Anyway, I can go on and on about this game, but I will simply close out here by stating that this was a special experience and I was glad for the opportunity to play this game.

9 out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037132481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1446390846}
review:
David Szymanski is one of those indie developers making "games as art." Even to open-minded players, that can be a turn-off. There is no lack of pretentious, patronizing, and often preachy nonsense out there, and that can understandibly sour gamers towards arthouse titles. But unlike those developers, Szymanski is creating profound, memorable experiences with compact, well-written narratives, and he is doing so with no agenda but his artistic vision.

My first of Szymanski's games was the free Fingerbones, which was strong enough to get me to pay for futher games. The second was the powerful The Moon Silver, which is by far my favorite of his stories. And the third is A Wolf in Autumn. All three games place an emphasis on psychological horror, and all three are short, playable in a single one-hour sitting. All three contain characters constructed through text, audio, and, for the playable characters, gameplay. You generally won't see character models on-screen, but that doesn't detract from the experience. Anyone who has played a well-crafted text-heavy game (or read a good book, for that matter) knows memorable characters are created through writing, not through visuals. Gameplay can be described, and not inaccurately, as "walking simulator with puzzles," and that's fine. That's all that needed.

There's not much I can say specifically without spoiling the experience of A Wolf in Autumn. When it intends to be beautiful, it's beautiful. When it intends to be spooky, it is. It's better than Fingerbones, though it doesn't live up to The Moon Silver, which does a better job of using its limitations to its advantage. Like all of Szymanski's games, it sticks with you. You'll be thinking about the story long after you finish playing. That's a compliment.

Bottom line: if you like psychological horror, aventure games, and you value games as a way to tell stories, you like A Wolf in Autumn. You'll like everything from Szymanski, in fact. My only suggestion is to start with Fingerbones, which, again, is free. If you enjoy that, you'll enjoy the rest. I can't wait to try The Music Machine!

review:
[b]"...and proud I will remain until I am nothing at all."[/b]

Ever since I've discovered David Syzmanski's games starting with [i]the Moon Sliver[/i], I got addicted. I'm not ashamed to declare that I'm addicted to beautiful, elegant and eerie atmospheres that he creates, veiling disturbing realities. [i]A Wolf in Autumn[/i] is no exception.

The sun raising on a beautiful shore line, waves cradling the shore on endless motions, bathed within the rays of sun themselves... Is this the scent of sea? No. Lights do shimmer through an old wooden wall, crafted either lazily, or without much skill. We are able to see an autumn garden through the cracks between planks. We are in a shed. Who are we? As we get out of the shed, we encounter an odd mechanism. As we push the button on the strange machine, a woman's voice calls us to warn that there are wild animals around. [u]"Go back to the shed, sweetie. There are wolves in the woods".[/u]

[i]A Wolf in Autumn[/i] presents us a dreamlike experience, in which we take the part of Autumn, a 9 year old girl. She is in an autumn garden and wanders around, hearing her mother's voice through some strange machinations around. As we keep our progress, things do take a turn for a darker nature. Concepts such as pride, nature, innocence and responsibility are discussed, and we once again face that the reality itself is much cruder and darker than any monster under our beds could possibly be.

The narration and the voice acting of the mother come into a spectacular combination, and carry you though a genuine uneasiness. Graphics do hail from basic unity, but seeing the display of light, shadows and colors in this specific manner, you are reminded that this is a game by David Syzmanski. Added background noises; growls, swaying trees and mechanical sounds, this is a brilliant success on atmospheric horror yet again!

As for gameplay, it might be defined as a short atmospheric horror + walking simulation with puzzle elements. It is a bit hard to tag these games with a genre, but I can most certainly tell that they carry artistic and philosophical quality. The whole game wouldn't take more than an hour, and it is intended to be completed on one sitting, as David Syzmanski's most games. So, there is no save game feature. We move around with WASD and carry some items to complete some basic puzzles. We are not capable of carrying more than one item at any time, so if we'd need the same item again, we have to look around to find it. I know it sounds a bit annoying, but it is a choice for story purposes. When the reason behind is explained, you'll be shocked. I promise.

[i]A Wolf in Autumn[/i] is a short, deep and dark experience rather than a game. I wouldn't recommend any game coming from David Syzmanski if you are looking for an adrenaline rush. If you'd like to indulge yourself with a shiver and some pondering afterwards, you are welcome.

Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ladystoryteller#curation]here[/url] - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

author: {'steamid': '76561198043768025', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1446079770}
review:
For 2 dollars, A Wolf in Autumn is very fairly priced. Expect a quick game, 30 minutes to an hour. You play as a young girl, locked in a shed and told to stay put. But ah, intrepid souls, we must escape. After the start up screen there is a bit of reading for the intro that vaguely sets the mood and gives a sense about what the story is going to be. As far as horror games go, this has some potential, and there are a few moments that are scary, but overall it falls more into the "a little creepy" category. From stumbling into the dark basement and scrambling for lights, to the howling of wolves just beyond the fence, the game never quite consistently reaches fear, but settles on more of a sense of unease. This isn't a bad thing, and I applaud the dev for avoiding use of jump scares and other poor horror tactics. 

Visually, the game does its job well enough, I could tell what's what and no textures or models were so bad they gave me pause. There is, however, one glaring exception. The lighting outside is really not good. I'm not sure what mood the dev was going for when he set those colors, but wonderland acid-trip was probably not it. With the colors a little too bright and the shadows  too dark, solving puzzles outsides becomes kind of a headache because of the contrast. Luckily, because of the games length you quickly descend into the basement, where the colors are more subdued and the darkness is more fitting and atmospheric. So although the terrible outdoor lighting gets the game off on a bad foot, it doesn't ruin the game by any means.

The puzzles are relatively simple, with several ways to solve many of them that are intuitive and logical. I would like a little more challenge, but I would rather have logical, simple puzzles, than challenging illogical ones. Not much more to say on these.

The story is simple, and could use some fleshing out, but for how long the game is it tells a pretty complete tale. Adding a few more puzzles and some more interactive story telling aspects could really help give the character a face, since even at the end I still know very little about her. As a psychological horror game goes, A Wolf in Autumn is acceptable, but there could be so much more. I would love to see it move through more phases, showing us a little more of each "layer" of the main character. 

Every now and again, a tin box in the middle of the room will light up and start beeping, which means you have a message from your mother waiting. The beeping wasn't too bad, if a little grating, but I feel like some of the horror was taken from the game by the fact that the tracks have to be played maunally. Also, as a note to the dev, why use the tin box when you already have a radio item that you can interact with? I feel like that could have been used, with static signaling when a message was available. Just a thought. The female voice actor used was good, although not stellar. There are no points where I was blown away by how good or bad she was, but she played the part and delivered the lines in a way that was consistent.

Overall, I enjoyed A Wolf in Autumn, although not the scariest horror game I've played, it did capture my curiousity with an interesting story. Id like to see where else this developer goes, since he seems to have a decent grasp of what makes a game scary, but needs to gain more experience in game design before he can really implement it.

[b]Tldr;[/b] This game is very indie, expect that. It is also very much worth 2 dollars, so you'll be getting what you pay for, but expect 2 dollars worth of game. 

Note to Dev: I really encourage you to make this game again later on, with more people involved in the design. I like the story and direction, and I would enjoy learning more about the characters and playing through the puzzles.

review:
While the puzzles took me time to get used to (maybe I never quite got used to them, as finding those solutions formed the bulk of my play time, but then again I am not a very good adventure gamer), the intense and rewarding experience that A Wolf In Autumn provides cannot be denied. Szymanski's storytelling prowess shows itself in every image, every sound, and most game interactions, creating an exploration of a topic that many other games shy away from (listen up 'cause gaming needs this. It's important).

A lot can be said about a user interface this smooth and simple that still yields so many different possible actions, but I still felt like there were unexplored gameplay possibilities this time around. Previous games felt tight and concise, without a wasted mechanic or item. Everything fed the tale, and the tale fed everything. Ultimately, I felt that the puzzle elements here could get in the way of the meat-and-potatoes (except where the two intertwined to wonderful effect with the button messages reacting to player actions).

Symbolism appears in abundance, and Szymanski uses that to reinforce the game's themes in smart ways. This is a game that will ask you to think about its content after it's complete. Maybe even play it a second time to help tie all of its elements together. It adds up to a whole that is equal parts thrilling (hinted threat), engaging (inquisitivity), and repulsive (overt threat). A masterful combination of horror craft.

The main takeaway is this (TL;DR): David Szymanski keeps getting better, in every sense. Technical improvements are obvious through screenshots. This game contains more classical game play than his previous titles. His stories are just as powerfully delivered as they have been since Fingerbones hit the indie horror scene.

And while some may contend that the game is too short (it is quite short), I contend that that is at least partially the point. The origins of literary horror took root in the short story, in the compact punch that format delivers best. These games are the interactive manifestation of that early horror tradition. You can't have Stephen King's long-winded ass without Poe, Hawthorne, and Lovecraft. And we can't rightly have unique interactive horror experiences without our short-form pioneers. Again, the work is important.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006541362', 'num_games_owned': 2760, 'num_reviews': 237, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1445969281}
review:
You're a girl, alone, in a locked shed: you easily escape from it only to find yourself in a fenced garden with weird machinery, threatening noises and an even worse voice addressing you.
A Wolf in Autumn is a short surreal horror game with a disturbing story and simple puzzles: if you've played other games by David Szymanski then you're familiar with the dreamlike, dark and weird atmospheres he's able to create (e.g. The Music Machine) and A Wolf in Autumn continues down the same road.

[b]PROS:[/b]

-weird art style with oversaturated colours and contrasting lights truly gives a dream/ nightmare feel to the game

-good sound design, the ominous noises manage to be unsettling

-strong voice acting

-good writing, I really appreciated the style used for ingame text and how things slowly made sense as I was playing the game 

-very disturbing and dark themes: the story behind the girl is unsettling and violent, the voice you hear can convey enough perceived violence and hate to become truly distressing

-straightforward puzzles reward exploration and logical thinking

[b]NEUTRAL:[/b]

-the oversaturated graphics won't be everyone's cup of tea

-you can only carry/ use one item at a time, the reason for this is eventually explained though

[b]CONS:[/b]

-you'll have to be careful where you drop an item when switching objects or risk having to hunt for it between the grass (thankfully, the most important items are given to you more than once)

-going back to the previous area saved my progress puzzle-wise but reset the position of every object, forcing me to get around to gather them and light candles again

-no subtitles

-it's quite simple, short as the Store page says (beaten in 45 minutes), basically no replay value


http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=542988982

Having played The Music Machine I was curious to see what the dev had managed to do this time and, despite the short length and simple gameplay, I must say A Wolf in Autumn left quite an impression on me. As said before Szymanski doesn't shy away from darker themes and he surely isn't afraid to hold back here: what the voice says to you, its extremely violent and hateful tone and the details of certain events are truly unpleasant.

I think it works so well cause, without spoiling anything, the story is about events that do happen in real life and I like to think that certain actual facts can be way scarier than an imaginary monster due to the fact they do really happen and'd affect us, people we know or be something we've seen in a newspaper.

The gameplay itself is decent, you'll have to explore around to find tools and then use the right one on the right object: sometimes the solution might be less straightforward than it first seems and a couple objects/ levers might require you to think a bit. There's not much of a challenge though, the game is more interested in telling you a story rather than challenging your brain.

A Wolf in Autumn felt like a distilled form of what the dev is known for as a short and extremely unsettling journey that, when played in the dark and with headphones on as recommended, game me a few goosebumps due to how immersed I was in a truly unpleasant and quite real scenario. It's a game I recommend as an example of psychological horror done right.
